data.title: Googletest tests

milestone.description: This release is the first that the new Steering Committee will be responsible for. Our aims are to process as many existing outstanding issues/pull requests as possible and implement good practises for the future of the engine, such as automatic compile/unit testing of pull requests, as well as managing the different release files.

data.body:
Most unit tests ported to googletest framework as described in #728 - see that issue for a full list of changes and detailed description of the new testing framework. I don't recommend looking through the list of changed files here - look at the linked issue and read individual commits if a particular unit test was close to your heart and you want to see what I did to it.

Note that the 20,000 removed lines are mostly from the Stanford bunny. It will be missed.

EDIT: Tests do not compile under GCC. Working on it.

data.title: Port async packet queue to Googletest
data.body: Due to time constraints on releasing 3.6, the async packet queue test was not ported as part of #728, just commented out. Iwt would be great to get it ported to the Googletest framework. https://github.com/GarageGames/Torque3D/blob/development/Engine/source/platform/async/test/asyncPacketQueueTest.cpp

data.title: Port zip tests to Googletest
data.body: Due to time constraints on 3.6 release, the zip tests were not ported as part of #728, just commented out. It'd be great if we could evaluate them and get them ported so we can unit test that part of the engine. https://github.com/GarageGames/Torque3D/tree/development/Engine/source/core/util/zip/test

data.title: OPENGL: MRTS left unexposed
data.body:
Not something likely to crop up prior to incorporation of both the defered and opengl forks, but we did note that

ShaderGenPrinterGLSL::printPixelShaderOutputStruct and ShaderGenPrinterGLSL::printPixelShaderCloser both presume single-target output

tim newel cooked up an initial take on a fix:
https://github.com/Azaezel/Torque3D/commit/3af587df148d4cff8e53cc92324683e9686aa4a1
and
https://github.com/Azaezel/Torque3D/commit/cbcfe4d3a00987f1acdb1583ebc137575a4b23a4
since using an actual glsl struct was giving us a bit of a hard time.
(proceeds from https://github.com/andr3wmac/Torque3D/commit/83d5ae48cbe9593b9136d49c956cc23f7eb359e8#diff-592f1531ed27aba9f6339b847f4709d9 )
Given this is a root-problem, and not a fork issue, reporting here and will clone the report on request.

data.title: Allow return status to be specified using quitWithStatus

milestone.description: This version will focus on processing two of the major outstanding pull requests, James Urquhart's [TorqueScript interpreter improvements](https://github.com/GarageGames/Torque3D/pull/81) and Tim Condon's [GUI additions](https://github.com/GarageGames/Torque3D/pull/545). Along with that we'll be bringing in lots of other TS-related enhancements, adding unit tests for TS to make sure we don't break your games, and processing even more of the outstanding issue list.

data.body:
Call `quitWithStatus(1)`, for example, to exit the program with a 1 status code. This is useful for unit tests and servers. Currently not implemented for Mac platform. Note that I haven't tested the Linux build yet because of VM issues, so I may rebase this at some point so it actually works on Ubuntu dedicated.

EDIT: The reason this is a separate command is because of this:

```
GlobalActionMap.bind(keyboard, escape, quit);
```

This will call `quit(1)` when the escape key is pressed because of the way TorqueScript works (AFAICT). Therefore to prevent incorrect default arguments from being passed, `quit` will always use code `0` and `quitWithStatus` will take an explicit code. `quitWithErrorMessage` has also been extended to optionally take a code.

data.title: Release 3.6

milestone.description: This release is the first that the new Steering Committee will be responsible for. Our aims are to process as many existing outstanding issues/pull requests as possible and implement good practises for the future of the engine, such as automatic compile/unit testing of pull requests, as well as managing the different release files.

data.body:
Release process:
- [ ] Finish all other [issues and PRs](https://github.com/GarageGames/Torque3D/issues?q=is%3Aopen+milestone%3A3.6+sort%3Aupdated-desc)
- [x] Update version numbers in source and other documents
- [ ] Build Windows binaries (i386, x64)
- [ ] Prepare packages
  - [ ] Bare executables
  - [ ] Full template with generated `.cached.dts` files
  - [x] Entire repository (handled by GitHub)
- [ ] Deploy packages
  - [ ] Bare executables to GitHub releases page
  - [ ] Everything to GarageGames
  - [ ] Everything to [gameupdates.org](http://www.gameupdates.org/)?
- [ ] Write and publish release blog

data.title: Fix scopeScene's use of Box3F constructor
data.body: The `Box3F` constructor accepting a single float [treats it as a diameter, not a radius](https://github.com/GarageGames/Torque3D/blob/d08e594316e69651b6b6c8a07063d9111b2af688/Engine/source/math/mBox.h#L249). Therefore we need to double `visibleDistance` before we pass it in.

data.title: Player mass defaults to 9
data.body: This is not a sensible default.

data.title: NavMesh scale does not make sense in script

milestone.description: This version will focus on processing two of the major outstanding pull requests, James Urquhart's [TorqueScript interpreter improvements](https://github.com/GarageGames/Torque3D/pull/81) and Tim Condon's [GUI additions](https://github.com/GarageGames/Torque3D/pull/545). Along with that we'll be bringing in lots of other TS-related enhancements, adding unit tests for TS to make sure we don't break your games, and processing even more of the outstanding issue list.

data.body: Because the NavMesh's default object box is 10 units big, setting the scale in script has to account for this. It would be better if its object box was unitary, and its scale defaulted to 10.

data.title: chat under GNU/Linux does not catch all typing focus
data.body:
Any assigned keys keep working normally while typing a message.
Including _the chat key_.

Example:
When binding chat to the letter "t" the message `Short messages work.` gets truncated to `Shor`.
Also all ingame actions triggered by keys _are_ triggered when using them in the message.
Torque3D should catch almost all typing focus while in chat mode.

This only seems to affect the GNU/Linux port.

data.title: Cannot use GroundCover on meshes
data.body: According to [this thread](http://www.beamng.com/threads/8108-Applying-ground-cover-to-mesh). For reference, [here's](https://github.com/GarageGames/Torque3D/blob/40cefe10023256c20ca9052027b58cd14514169e/Engine/source/T3D/fx/groundCover.cpp#L1231) the culprit.

data.body: Oftentimes you _don't_ have most animations defined in the Player shape. No need to fuss, it'll be obvious if they're supposed to be there anr they're not.

data.title: Fixed Vehicle crash on changing datablock shape in editor for #189

milestone.description: This release is the first that the new Steering Committee will be responsible for. Our aims are to process as many existing outstanding issues/pull requests as possible and implement good practises for the future of the engine, such as automatic compile/unit testing of pull requests, as well as managing the different release files.

data.body:
To fix #189 I separated out parts of `ShapeBaseData::preload` (and `preload` in descendant classes) that referred to `mShape` into `_loadShape` and called `_loadShape` when `shapeName` is changed from scripts by using `addProtectedField`. Now, Vehicle will `AssertFatal` when you give it a shape with no collision mesh, instead of crashing nastily later. See #739 also.

Note that crashes are still possible. For example, changing a `Vehicle` to a shape that has no animations will go badly.

data.title: Allow main.cs to be compiled to a DSO
data.body: Currently, the root `main.cs` file is not compiled to a DSO, and is not loaded if this is done. Users should have the option of distributing a compiled root mainfile.

data.title: Simplify compiler ast

milestone.description: This release is the first that the new Steering Committee will be responsible for. Our aims are to process as many existing outstanding issues/pull requests as possible and implement good practises for the future of the engine, such as automatic compile/unit testing of pull requests, as well as managing the different release files.

data.body:
This modification abstracts bytecode generation in the compiler so there is no longer a precompile step, in effect making it easier to modify the bytecode generated by the compiler (no more size mismatches!).

As an added bonus, codeStream entries for the StringTable entries have been expanded to 64bits, allowing compiled scripts to work properly on 64bit systems (when TORQUE_64 is defined). The codeStream is similarly expanded for 32bit systems, allowing for scripts to work transparently between 32bit and 64bit platforms. This essentially follows similar code in Torque2D.

In addition similar to Torque2D OP_CALLFUNC_RESOLVE can now automatically converted to OP_CALLFUNC to speed up function calls (excluding methods). Since this can cause problems with future function lookups when packages are activated, it is by default disabled. However it can be turned on via the COMPILER_OPTIMIZE_FUNCTION_CALLS define.

As this pull request touches on the internals of the bytecode compiler, it's entirely possible something completely unexpected will break. I have however tested this code on a production T3D game and as of yet have not noticed any problems. In any event there is a complementary GIST located at https://gist.github.com/jamesu/4966d4689689d058f38a which goes through a few basic tests related to code patching which may prove insightful. Output of this script is currently identical to stock T3D.

data.title: Outpost testbed.
data.body:
contains: multi-layer material terrain, waterplane, wheeledvehicle, respawning AI turret, static mesh, particleemitternode(s), timeofday, forest, groundcover, postfx preset (edit: and a storm, physicszone, and decal and mesh road. sadly, no partidge in a pear tree)

#769 for groundcover material definitions, #771 to ensure water doesn't trap the player.
